|Title=Know how to remove a venous line
|Description=None
|Topic=Monitoring and/or prognosis
|Contributors= Philippe Lacroix, Simon Rickenbach
|Order=5}}

Removal of the venous access requires compression of the insertion point to limit the risk of haematoma.

Be careful in the event of haemostasis problems and/or an insertion point that is difficult to compress.

Risk of gas embolism when removing a central venous line in the superior vena cava: removal should be carried out in the supine position, asking the conscious non-ventilated patient to stop breathing or breathe out during removal.

question.question: When removing a central venous line in the superior vena cava, what position should the patient be in to minimize the risk of gas embolism?
question.option_b: Lying on their side to allow for easier access
question.option_c: Supine position, asking the conscious non-ventilated patient to stop breathing or breathe out during removal
